Subject: Re: Evolving Coordinated Quadruped Gaits with the HyperNEAT Generative Encoding
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=283334584; y=RrmTyhrrROxQW-8GdJCQk1CmI2MQPlnho2lX1bfTEBkKlvRou_UghmbLdA

Hi Ken.

I agree that the model morphology is critical. When I was playing =
with 
my model, I noticed that there is a great difference in performance 
=
for even a slight modification, like longer vs. shorter legs. 
There is som=
ething else that is important in case HyperNEAT is being 
used for this. Th=
e substrate should represent the model's actual 
geometry in space. In gene=
ral, it is possible that HyperNEAT can find 
a solution for the task given =
almost any substrate, but I think that 
the best results will be obtained w=
hen a substrate that copies the 
model's geometry is used. After all, it is=
 the geometric priori 
knowledge that provides the bias for HyperNEAT. 
Let=
 me note another thing, concerning leaky integrators. Cyclic 
activity in t=
he neurons has to be encouraged via some kind of fitness 
constraint. If no=
t, there will be a great deal of computational time 
wasted for evaluating =
stabilizing networks that produce a step or two, 
but not real walking. Thi=
s is why I like Jeff's approach with 
inputting the sine wave - in this cas=
e all networks are guaranteed to 
oscillate in some way. 
I guess this is n=
ot anything new to you, but I am definitely 
interested in seeing how well =
your experiments performed. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth =
Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> We have actually been running biped evol=
ution experiments recently 
at
> UCF because we would like to use it as a t=
est domain in the future 
as
> well.  In our efforts, we have learned a cou=
ple things that may 
answer
> some questions:
> 
> First, leaky integrator =
neurons definitely work and work well.  They
> can produce oscillatory moti=
on without a sine wave (or any kind of
> oscillator) input.  So there is no=
 doubt that a sine wave is
> unnecessary.  However, Jeff, if in your domain=
 somehow leaky
> integrators hurt that is interesting.  I wonder why that w=
ould be.
> 
> Second, the model morphology is critical.  You cannot simply =
expect
> any biped to walk.  Great care is necessary to ensure that 
everyt=
hing
> about the model makes sense and is proportionate.  
> 
> We're still=
 in the midst of an extensive study, and we will let
> everyone know all th=
e details when it's completed.  
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com,=
 Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> >
> > > Very interesting paper! :)
> > 
> > =
Thanks. I'm glad you enjoyed it.
> > 
> > > It reminds me about the experim=
ents I made with HyperNEAT for
> > > controlling biped robots. Did you try =
using leaky-integrator 
based
> > > neurons for the substrate?
> > > I foun=
d them very useful for generating
> > > oscillation patterns. Substrates of=
 leaky integrators with 
tanh()
> > > activation functions produce oscillat=
ions much easier than 
others.
> > > Hm.. I should really try with robots w=
ith 3 legs or more. 
Getting
> > > biped walking with HyperNEAT is perhaps =
too ambitious right now.
> > 
> > I have thought a lot about your biped exp=
eriment. I'd be really
> interested
> > in hearing your opinion, and that o=
f anyone else on this list, as 
to why
> > your results were so different f=
rom mine. I found that it did not
> take that
> > much tuning to get HyperN=
EAT to evolve really good quadruped 
gaits.
> But, as
> > you note, it was =
much harder to evolve gaits in your biped setup.
> > 
> > I can suggest a f=
ew hypotheses as to what explains the difference.
> These are
> > not mutua=
lly exclusive, and it might not be the case that any one 
of
> them
> > exp=
lains most of the difference, but instead that they add up to 
the
> > diff=
erence. 
> > 
> > 1) Biped gaits are harder to evolve than quadruped gaits
=
> > 2) The sine wave I provided made it really easy to evolve periodic
> ga=
its.
> > 3) Leaky integrators hurt performance for some reason
> > 4) I use=
d a PID-based setup, where the target angle was the output
> of the
> > neu=
ral net (and not the force to be applied)
> > 
> > There are other differen=
ces of course, such as the inputs and the
> number of
> > hidden nodes. 
> =
> 
> > I'll make a few comments on each hypothesis.
> > 
> > 1) Biped gaits=
 are harder to evolve than quadruped gaits.
> > 
> > This would be easy to =
test by simply trying a biped with my setup.
> > Unfortunately, I have some=
 other obligations that will prevent me 
from
> > testing this anytime soon=
, but if you (or anyone else) would like 
to
> give it
> > a try, that woul=
d be cool. I can send you the code I used. One 
would
> just
> > need to ch=
ange the quadruped into a biped. Alternately, you could 
try to
> > mimic m=
y setup in your "Ultimate NEAT" ;-).
> > 
> > I do have access to a huge co=
mputing cluster. So, if someone makes
> the code
> > modifications to my se=
tup (which I know compiles on our cluster) 
and
> sends
> > them to me, I c=
an do a batch of runs.
> > 
> > 2) The sine wave I provided made it really =
easy to evolve periodic 
gaits
> > 
> > This would be an easy test. You cou=
ld just plug a sine as an input
> into your
> > biped. Note: I found that t=
he period of the sine wave made a huge
> > difference. If I made it too fas=
t or too slow, evolution basically
> ignored
> > the signal. Within the ran=
ge of periods that worked, I found that 
I got
> > different types of gaits=
 with different period speeds. With slower
> periods,
> > I observed cool t=
ortoise-like gaits with left-right symmetry. With
> medium
> > periods, I g=
ot the gaits in the paper. With faster periods, I saw
> slightly
> > more f=
rantic versions of the gaits in the paper.
> > 
> > As a side note, I tried=
 to evolve the period for a short while and
> it was a
> > miserable failur=
e. I'd like to try that again, and would be
> interested to
> > hear people=
's thoughts as to why it failed. Maybe I'll describe 
that
> attempt
> > in=
 another email. If someone out there is curious, let me know and
> I'll sen=
d
> > it out sooner rather than later.
> > 
> > 3) Leaky integrators hurt p=
erformance for some reason.
> > 
> > I did not try leaky integrators. Did y=
ou ever try your setup 
without
> them?
> > 
> > I did not try them because=
 the default sigmoid neurons worked so
> well out of
> > the box that I did=
 not experiment with alternatives. Both Ken 
(during
> > preliminary conver=
sations about the paper) and one of the papers'
> reviewers
> > asked about=
 leaky integrators, so there is clearly some interest 
out
> there
> > in s=
eeing how leaky integrators would compare to the neurons
> > we used in the=
 paper.
> > 
> > Do most of you feel leaky integrators would perform better=
? Why? I 
have
> > never worked with them, nor do I know that much about th=
em, so I
> don't have
> > great instincts on this front. Is it possible tha=
t they could have 
made
> > things worse in Petar's setup?
> > 
> > It woul=
d be cool to test them out in my setup. Again, I won't be
> able to get
> >=
 to this in the near future so if someone out there wants to swap
> them in=
 and
> > give it a go, that would be interesting.
> > 
> > 4) I used a PID-=
based setup, where the target angle was the output
> of the
> > neural net =
(and not the force to be applied).
> > 
> > I could not figure out whether =
your setup did this as well. What
> were the
> > outputs in your system?
> =
> ---------
> > 
> > Do you think any/all of these hypotheses explain the d=
ifference in
> results?
> > What other likely hypothesis am I missing (I am=
 sure there are 
lots).
> > 
> > Thanks again for checking out the paper,
>=
 > Jeff
> > 
> > PS. Tripods would be fun. I also think adding feet and a f=
lexible 
torso
> > would be interesting.
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > > 
> > > Peter
=
> > > 
> > > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jeff Clune <jclune@> wrote:
> > >=
> 
> > >> Hello all-
> > >> 
> > >> Ever since I first understood HyperNEAT=
 I have wanted to see 
how it
> > > would
> > >> perform at controlling leg=
ged robots.
> > >> 
> > >> A paper I wrote on that subject was just accepte=
d, so I can 
share it
> > > with
> > >> you now. 
> > >> 
> > >> A copy of =
the paper, and videos of the simulated robots, can be
> > > obtained
> > >>=
 here:
> > >> 
> > >> 
> > > 
http://devolab.msu.edu/SupportDocs/EvolvingCo=
ordinatedGaitsWithHyperNE
> > > AT
> > >> 
> > >> 
> > >> I hope you find i=
t interesting. Please let me know what you 
think,
> > > or if you
> > >> h=
ave any questions.
> > >> 
> > >> 
> > >> Here is the cite and abstract:
> =
> >> 
> > >> Clune, J., Beckmann, B. E., Ofria, C., & Pennock, R. T.
> > >>=
 Evolving coordinated gaits with the HyperNEAT generative 
encoding.
> > >>=
 
> > >> Proceedings of the IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computing 
Specia=
l
> > > Section
> > >> on Evolutionary Robotics, 2009. Trondheim, Norway. T=
o appear.
> > >> 
> > >> Legged robots show promise for complex mobility ta=
sks, such as
> > > navigating
> > >> rough terrain, but the design of their=
 control software is both
> > > challenging
> > >> and laborious. Tradition=
al evolutionary algorithms can produce 
these
> > >> controllers, but requi=
re manual decomposition or other problem
> > >> simplification because conv=
entionally-used direct encodings 
have
> > > trouble
> > >> taking advantag=
e of a problem's regularities and symmetries. 
Such
> > > active
> > >> int=
ervention is time consuming, limits the range of potential
> > > solutions,=
 and
> > >> requires the user to possess a deep understanding of the 
probl=
em's
> > >> structure. This paper demonstrates that HyperNEAT, a new and
> =
> > promising
> > >> generative encoding for evolving neural networks, can =
evolve
> > > quadruped gaits
> > >> without manually decomposing the proble=
m. Analyses suggest that
> > > HyperNEAT is
> > >> successful because it em=
ploys a generative encoding that can 
more
> > > easily
> > >> reuse phenot=
ypic modules. It is also one of the first
> > > neuroevolutionary
> > >> al=
gorithms that exploits a problem's geometric symmetries, 
which may
> > > a=
id its
> > >> performance. We compare HyperNEAT to FT-NEAT, a direct encodi=
ng
> > > control, and
> > >> find that HyperNEAT is able to evolve impressi=
ve quadruped 
gaits and
> > > vastly
> > >> outperforms FT-NEAT. Comparativ=
e analyses reveal that HyperNEAT
> > > individuals
> > >> are more holistic=
ally affected by genetic operators, resulting 
in
> > > better
> > >> coord=
ination of the quadruped's legs. Overall, the results 
suggest
> > > that
>=
 > >> HyperNEAT is a powerful algorithm for evolving control systems 
for
>=
 > > complex,
> > >> yet regular, devices, such as robots.
> > >> 
> > >>  =

> > >> 
> > >> 
> > >> 
> > >> 
> > >> Cheers,
> > >> Jeff Clune
> > >>

e@
